sols_html:
For convenience, let’s recall our results from part (b) and part(c):

\[\begin{aligned} \mathrm{cond}(A) &= \|A\|\|A^{-1}\| = \max\{1, |a|, 2\}\max\{1, 1/|a|, 1/2\} \\ &= \max\{|a|, 2\}\max\{1, 1/|a|\}\end{aligned}\]

and cond(A) is not defined when a = 0. This suggests considering three cases for \(\displaystyle |a|\):

  • Case 1: If \(0 < |a| \leq 1\) then

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle \mathrm{cond}(A) = (2)(1/|a|) = 2/|a|\end{aligned}\]

  • Case 2: If \(1 \leq |a| \leq 2\) then

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle \mathrm{cond}(A) = (2)(1) = 2\end{aligned}\]

  • Case 3: If \(2 \leq |a|\) then

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle \mathrm{cond}(A) = |a|(1) = |a|\end{aligned}\]

statement_html:
Let

\[\begin{aligned} A = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & a & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 2 \end{bmatrix}\end{aligned}\]

where a is a real number.

(d) Sketch a graph of cond(A) as a function of a for \(-\infty\) < a < \(\infty\)
